0.8 K for 1 gram is not really that crazy if you are working with dil-fridges. Most dil-fridges can go down to 20 mK with no lasers involved. Some of the more sophisticated ones can achieve as low as 15 mK. And if you stick the He3 reservoir of the dil-fridge inside of a slowly relaxing electro-magnet, then you can achieve microK still with no lasers. And that would work for most of the ~1gr objects. If you then decide to involve lasers you could probably reach tens or hundreds of nK. So lasers are great for cooling stuff down, but if you want to cool down something big you better use He3 and magnets.

I thought about the universal constant, and that perhaps the boundary of the speed of light might have an inversion similar to music: if there is an upper limit to how fast objects can move, could there be a lower limit, which might be defined by 1/C? And perhaps 0 degrees Kelvin is not possible in the same way that traveling faster than the speed of light is not possible?
Again, I'm not a physicist, but I thought I'd throw that idea out there.

There's another physics of laser cooling in solid state which you do not talk about. This works by exciting atomic or excitonic transitions by using a laser that is just short of energy of this transition. In the process phonons from the material are absorbed and if the material has a high quantum efficiency, it gives out all of that energy as light which is higher in energy. We use this method to cool Yb3+ doped YLF crystals in our lab. This has also apparently worked for Cadmium sulfide semiconductor but although published in Nature it has not been reproduced yet.

The reason absolute zero is unreachable is not due to the uncertainty principle. The uncertainty principle is the reason that even at a hypothetical absolute zero, there is still thermal energy remaining (called zero-point energy). Or in other words, as you approach absolute zero, the thermal energy does not approach zero but some finite positive value.

The reason absolute zero is unreachable is due entirely to classical thermodynamics and is true with or without uncertainty.

The uncertainty principle it is not related with the "unknowing" of position or momentum (in general with conjugate variables) in the sense that we cannot measure without error these variables. The rigorous formulation implies infinitely exact instruments to measure X or P. The deltas in the formula just are variances, no uncertainties. Obviously we cannot perform a simultaneous measure of this non compatible operators, but the ensemble concept saves the day... ^_^

Cool video (bad pun intended) :) But you omitted the crucial point to laser cooling actually working. After the photon is absorbed, it's not the end of the story yet! An electron will move in said atom to a higher energy state, and will eventually go back to original (as in, lowest) energy state, and emit a photon (with equal wavelength and hence energy and momentum). But it will do so in random direction. Hence, over many absorptions-emissions, overall momentum gain from emitting photons will cancel out - so in the end we successfully slowed the particle down in one direction :)
